65536.name: Dragon (Issue 198 - Oct 1993)
rpgissuearticle: Campaign Journal: Scimitars against the Dark
The Dragon Project - Mr. Josh Wellmeat
You can run - but you'll only die tired
65536.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XVIII, No. 5
Issue #198
October 1993

"Ready for an October walk?"

Cover by Michael Scott

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

65537.description:
This is a memory game for Kids.

The aim of this game is to deliver as many toys as possible by collecting Wish list cards.

The players must take a Wish list card and find the toys which are on this Wish list card.
If the toy revealed is on the Wish list card (and is the required one in the case of a specific list): the player leaves this Toy card visible and can continue turning over cards as long as he does not make a mistake. He can also choose to let the player on his left take his turn.

The toy revealed is not on the Wish list card (or is not the required one in the case of a specific list): the player must therefore turn the Toy card face down and loses his turn. The player on his immediate left now has a turn.

When the last Wish List card has been won, everyone counts the number of toys on the Wish List cards that they won. The player with the largest number of toys wins the game. In case of a tie, all the players concerned are the winners.
65537.name: Surprises

65538.name: Dragon (Issue 201 - Jan 1994)
rpgissuearticle: Seven Steps to a Successful Castle
65538.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XVIII, No. 8 (erroneously listed as No. 7)
Issue #201
January 1994

"Civilized centers of adventure"

Cover by Mark Poole, credited as Mark Pool.

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

65539.name: The Games We Play
65539.description:
The students will get hands-on experience in a section of game-theory that models many common situations in which two parties make a decision with an outcome that depends on the other parties choice. They will understand the four cell matrix often used to model games in game theory, and learn how different configurations of the scores in this matrix affect the tactics.

The aim of the game is to gain as many points as possible during the game. The score can be compared both to the other players and to own highest score in previous games.

Components:
52 cards

65540.name: Minut spelet
65540.description:
This is a game about mathematics. Each round the active players throws 14 6-sides dice marked with numbers between 1 and 15. The goal is then to use these numbers in 4 mathematical calculations using addition, subtraction, multiplication and division. A timer is used to determine time allowed. All numbers in the used dice will added together and all unused dice is then subtracted to produce the score. Each players plays a number of rounds, but the actual winning conditions isn't specified in the rules, this must be agreed upon in advance.

You need to be fairly good at counting to be successful in this game. For that reason it usually isn't fun for kids under 10 or so, even if the rules are very simple.

65541.name: Dragon (Issue 203 - Mar 1994)
rpgissuearticle: Bonus - The AMAZING ENGINE System Guide
65541.description:
Dragon Magazine
Vol. XVIII, No. 10 (erroneously listed as No. 9)
Issue #203
March 1994

"Science fantasy will blow you away"

Cover by Tim Bradstreet and Fred Fields.

The table of contents is detailed in the Article list below.

65543.name: A Problem of Manors
65543.description:
Publisher Blurb:

A classic adventure by the hand of Chris Clark and Gary Gygax! Here the avatars must explore the lonely road and the old Manor house, whose owner has vanished without a trace! Peter the proprietor of the lonely Fireside Inn has lost his servant, his mules, his wagon and a whole portage of wine. His wife is hounding him and his accounts are dry. Peter is not amused. He sent the load by a logger road to the Count who lives in the not distant Manor House. An odd duck, the Count always orders loads of wine, but precious little supplies. He has not been from since the shipment left. Peter is need of some worthy adventurers who will trek the lonely road through the tumbled forests and find his property and his best costumer! A Problem of Manors is designed for 4-8 mounted Avatars of a medium level of playing experience

65544.name: Gary Gygax's Cosmos Builder
65544.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Cosmos Builder provides fantasy cosmologists the tools to create a unique depiction of the realms above and below (and everything in between) that can be incorporated into any setting. While this book cannot include all possible options, it hits upon the most common elements of planes of existence and offers insight for deviating from and blending these elements to suit your needs, to craft new dimensions and the strange worlds that exist on them and where diverse dimension meet.

This book is a toolbox, filled with ready-to-assemble components that will allow you to quickly flesh out your vision of a cosmology. These tools are designed to let you to share your vision with others so they can adopt your cosmology (or portions thereof) to their campaign, regardless of which game system they use. The only thing they require is knowledge of how the tools in this book work, or an explanation from you about how your friends can use your cosmology with their preferred game systems.

65546.name: 22 Ku-du
65546.description:
From the Publishers web site:
In Brief: 22 Ku-du is the wood tile math crossword game that's fun for all ages. Easily adaptable to all skill levels. Make all your rows and columns total 22. Learn while you play. 108 all-wood tiles

In Detail
Each player draws 7 tiles to begin play. Players make crosswords of numbers so that each grouping adds up to 22. As tiles are used to make a "22" a player yells "Ku-Do" and draws more tiles so that they are always working with 7 tiles. Play continues until all tiles are gone. Each "22" scores 1 point. Use of two of the same number in the same equation scores an extra point and three of the same number scores two extra points. Each player checks the other player's crossword and scores if they find any errors.

Many variations of play are left to the player or teams, depending on age or desire. Players can determine the number of rounds for each game, can use dice to set a new "goal" number in each round, or can use the color number tiles as either positive or negative numbers. Many different variations are possible to enhance the game and match the players skill level.

65548.name: Step Lively Shuffleboard
65548.description: Step Lively is a shuffleboard game. Instead of flicking or pushing the pucks. You use the ramp on the end of the playing board to launch your pucks into the scoring areas. Instead of a flat playing surface the gameboard is made up of stepped areas. You can adjust the height of the ramp to adjust the speed, at which your puck will launch and you can also turn the ramp to adjust the angle, to aim your shots more accurately.

65550.description:
Book of Mormon Characters is a simple card game for LDS families in which players attempt to complete the "Books" of various Book of Mormon prophets. Each prophet has four cards with various facts about his life as well as an Aztec-style illustration. Players seek to collect all four cards of a prophet by asking other players for cards the contain the image, fact, or name of the prophet they are missing. The winner is the player with the most books completed once the game is completed.

The rules include four variants that decrease difficulty for children and increase it for experts.
65550.name: Book of Mormon Characters

65551.name: Letterbox
65551.description: Each player begins the game with a set of tiles. Each set contains every letter of the alphabet with the vowels repeated for a total of thirty one. Players alternate turns playing tiles in a three-by-three grid. Players score for each two and three letter word they make during their turns. The player with the most points when both players have used all their tiles is the winner.

65552.name: Six Day Bike Race
65552.description: Bike racing game where you spin a wheel to determine movement and points. Comes with a small metal board (24x38cm). Published by the Lindstrom Tool & Toy Co. from Bridgestone, Connecticut, US.

65554.name: Sounds Like a Plan
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGB Volume 81 - Family Games, Part 1: Wits and Wagers Family Edition, Word on the Street Junior, Sounds Like A Plan
65554.description:
From the publisher's website:

What's the best plan for climbing Mt. Everest? How about the worst plan for making a million bucks? Find out in this party game that's all about giving outrageous advice! Select a card containing a piece of advice that best fits the judge's chosen activity. Score points if the judge takes your advice, but keep in mind that plans change with the roll of a die… You might have to give out bad advice, your grandma's advice, or even advice from a psychic! Take our advice and play today!

65555.name: Blast Off!
65555.description:
From the back cover:
"Get ready to blast your Bounty Head bebop game into space with Bounty Head Bebop: Blast Off! a new supplement packed with everything you need go after your mark in the cold, quiet deeps of space.

You will find:
Ship Creation rules to give your bounty hunters the ride they always deserved.
Ship edges and flaws for personalizing a ship and giving it that extra oomph in combat.
A complete map of the Ceres belt where all sorts of trouble awaits.
A few famous ships of the galaxy.
The rides of the worst criminal scum in the galaxy.

Bounty Head Bebop: Blast Off! take the fight to space and brung the bad guys home. Crime does pay."

boardgamehonor: 2011 Golden GeekBest Children's Board Game Nominee
65556.description:
From the publisher's website:

Step into the fierce and furry world of full-contact Sumo hamster wrestling! Using magnetic force, maneuver your Sumo hamster and try to knock your opponent out of the ring. It's a contest of bulk as much as brawn, so feed your hamster every chance you get! Win the most rounds and claim the title of Sumo Ham Slam Grand Champ!
65556.name: Sumo Ham Slam

65557.description:
From the publisher's website:

It's rush hour at the Ring-a-Ding Diner and you must hurry to serve a table full of hungry customers! Roll the die to add dishes to your tray. Roll a Free Meal or snag the Special of the Day to help fill your order. And if you roll a bell, it's a mad dash to grab your grub before another player beats you to the lunch! Be the first to complete all your orders and - DING! - you're the winner!
65557.name: Order's Up!

65559.description:
From the publisher's website:

A batch of yummy cupcakes is fresh out of the oven and it's time to decorate! Shake the sprinkle shaker and see what colorful shapes pour out. If any match a cupcake, add them to the card. Collect the most cards and winning is a piece of cake!
65559.name: Take the Cake
boardgamepodcastepisode: 36 – The Family Gamers Podcast – Learning through Games

65560.name: Campaign Cartographer 3
65560.description:
From the Publisher's Website:

Campaign Cartographer 3 is ProFantasy Software's flagship map-making software. CC3 gives you everything you need to create great maps for games, books and publishing. There are symbols and tools for overland maps from all ages, buildings, floorplans, heraldry, and many other uses. CC3, on its own, lets you create more and better maps, more quickly, than any comparable software. With the new features introduced in the latest versions, you can quickly create very attractive maps with effects usually found only in high-end graphics programs.

Do you have what it takes to create your own world?

CC3 is the fastest and most powerful map-making software for gamers. So if you're a busy person who wants the best, this is the software for you. In minutes you can learn all you need to rapidly create beautiful maps for campaigns, games and even real-world applications.

A few simple but powerful tools do it all, and you can learn what you need in a matter of minutes. But CC3's new simplicity doesn't mean less power. In fact, quite the reverse. CC3 gives you easy access to a huge choice of mapping symbols, styles and types. CC3 gives you fingertip control over every aspect of your mapping. With CC3, you draw exactly what and how you want.

Whenever you need designs, whether it's roleplaying games or wargames, fantasy, modern or SF, CC3 can help you create them. From entire worlds and countries, to floor-plans and furniture, CC3 can do it. You can map out your entire campaign world, place your troops in the field, or chart your galactic empire.

So, who uses CC3?

Authors, games designers and thousands of gamers and have mapped out the worlds of their imagination with CC3. We've improved CC3 to match their needs. Our mail-list users are extraordinarily helpful and resourceful - if you want ideas, they'll help. If you buy CC3, you are joining a huge, friendly community of like-minded designers. There are hundreds of user websites with a huge variety of maps. After nine years of software manufacture, we bring you quality plus diversity.

65561.name: Dungeon Designer 3
65561.description:
From the Publisher's Website:

The design revolution goes underground!

In the Stygian gloom of the dungeon the party watches nervously as the thief picks the lock on the huge chest.

"Got it!" he cries as the lid creaks upwards.

"What, no treasure?" exclaims the fighter in disgust.

"No wait! There's a map! This map in fact" says the Game Master, laying out a brilliantly designed, full-colour dungeon map, complete with winding corridors, echoing halls, secret doors, plunging chasms and cunning traps.

If you're a Game Master you obviously take your gaming seriously, and the Dungeon Designer 3 add-on for CC3 is the quickest and easiest way to bring serious realism, excitement, and true nastiness to your dungeons and floor-plans.

Whether you're designing a complete dungeon or just the floor-plan for your local inn or temple, Dungeon Designer 3 gives you all the tools you'll ever need to create corridors, caves and rooms of all shapes and sizes, plus more than 500 stunning symbols, from simple doors and windows to devious traps, ornate coffins, lifelike statues, sacred altars, tempting treasure, and more.

Dungeon Designer 3 is an add-on to Campaign Cartographer.

Get real.
Get Dungeon Designer 3.
Make your players feel they're really there.

65564.description:
"If the US Navy has it, so do you! "

Hornet Leader – Carrier Air Operations is a huge game based on the material seen in our Vassal/PDF games. We have also further enhanced the game systems and weapon values to make them fully consistent with the new systems seen in Phantom Leader.

Hornet Leader spans all aspects of US naval aviation throughout the service life of the F/A-18 Hornet from 1983 to the present day.

The game places you in command of the pilots and aircraft of a squadron of U.S. Navy strike aircraft in hostile campaigns around the world. The aircraft and weapons available for each campaign are historically accurate.

A major part of the game is mission planning. You decide how to arm your aircraft and which pilots are best for the mission. Pilots are rated for skill level. Deciding which pilots to fly each mission is a major consideration. Your pilots will become fatigued with every mission. If you fly a pilot too often, his skills will degrade. Your pilots also gain experience with every mission flown. This makes for some great decision-making. Should you keep flying the top pilots and further fatigue them to get the job done, or fly the new guys to prep them for the tough missions ahead?

See also: Leader series games by Dan Verssen
65564.name: Hornet Leader: Carrier Air Operations
boardgameexpansion: Hornet Leader: Cthulhu Conflict

65565.description:
The play-anywhere game of flicking fun!

Flicochet is a simple yet strategic dexterity flicking game that can be played on any table or flat surface.

Try and flick your discs as close as possible to the jack, while hitting your opponent's discs out of the way!
Late in the round, you may move the jack itself to improve your position. Take aim and watch it ricochet across the table! But don't knock it off, or you'll pay a heavy price!

For 2 players or 3-6 players in teams.
65565.name: Flicochet

boardgamehonor: 2012 Charles S. Roberts Best Post-Napoleonic to Pre-World War 2 Era Board Wargame Nominee
65566.description:
One of the three games split off from the earlier Battles of 1866: Frontier Battles project from APL, this game covers five different smaller battles from the Austro-Prussian War. These battles are... Trautenau, Soor, Nachod, Skalitz, and Gitschin.

This game uses the same system as War of the States: Gettysburg, 1863 and War of the States: Chickamauga & Chattanooga which is similar to the Rome at War and Eagles Of The Empire series as well. In this game, the units are Prussian, Austrian, and Saxon infantry brigades artillery batteries, and cavalry regiments. The pieces are moved around topographic maps of the various battlegrounds. Combat is resolved using by rolling a number of dice equal to the total combat strength of units involved in combat, with hits scored on a result of 6.
65566.name: Battles of 1866: Frontier Battles
boardgameexpansion: Battles of 1866: German Armies
boardgamefamily: Wars of the States and Empires

65567.name: Just Typical
65567.description:
Just Typical is a party game where players controversial statements about men and women. Those who find themselves in agreement with the other players more often will win.

Each turn, the active player draws a card from the deck, which could be a Controversy Card or a Just Typical Card - which is which is marked on the back of the card. In either case, the active player chooses one of three statements on the card and reads it aloud.

Controversy Cards have statements that refer to women, men, or relationships, such as "Women make better diplomats.", or "More alcohol is consumed on a hen night than a stag night." Players then secretly vote, using voting cards, as to whether they Agree or Disagree with the statement.

Just Typical Cards describe behaviours or situations, such as "Shopping for things that are not needed." or "Putting an empty milk carton back in the fridge." Players secretly vote, this time voting for if they thing that trait is "Typically Male" or "Typically Female".

Once everyone has voted, the votes are revealed. The players in the majority score +1 point, those in the minority score -1 point (but never going below 0). In the case of a tie, the active player's choice is considered the majority for scoring purposes.

The first player to reach 14 points wins.

boardgamehonor: 2010 Spiel des Jahres Recommended
2011 Hra roku Nominee
2012 Hungarian Board Game Award  Winner
2012 Hungarian Board Game Award Nominee
65568.description:
Jäger und Sammler is set in the Stone Age. Every player has control over a tribe of 4 hunter/gatherers. The game consists of two main phases: The summer phase and the winter phase. The aim of the game is to collect as many tiles as possible. Players have two movement points per turn and are only allowed to move to untaken tiles. When a player leaves a tile he gets to take it and place it in front of him. Food and artifacts are kept face down, but weapons and mammoths are kept face up. Whoever hunts down the biggest mammoth in the summer phase will start the winter phase.

Players also have to visit the four winter camps during the summer to store supplies for the upcoming winter. If a player is not able to visit all four camps during summer, he will have fewer hunters in the winter phase.

There are a lot of different tiles:
- Food tiles score 1 to 3 points at the end of the game, depending on the type of food.
- Rare and valuable artifact tiles increase in value depending on the number of identical tiles you collected.
- Weapons are used to hunt down mighty mammoths.
- Path-tiles remain on the board and guarantee a minimum amount of maneuverability.
- Caves are connected with each other and may be used to cover big distances while moving.

This game is based on the same prototype as Zombiegeddon.
65568.name: Jäger und Sammler

65569.name: Geometric Gin
65569.description:
The players will be able to calculate perimeter and area of triangles, squares, rectangles, and trapezoids. They will also be able to categorize triangles by determining whether they are right, isosceles, acute, or obtuse. In the affective domain, the players will enjoy applying their geometric skills in a fun and exciting game.

The object of the game is to get 'Gin'. This entails getting a correct combination of three and four cards. As in Gin, the cards must be categorized by 'suit'. The suits for this game are perimeter, area, or triangles. The cards must first be shuffled and seven cards should be dealt to each player. The deck should then be placed face down with one card placed face up as a discard pile. The play goes in a clockwise direction and begins with the player to the left of the dealear. At each players turn, the player has the option to pick the face up card or one from the deck. The player must then discard one card in the discard (face up) pile. Play continues until someone gets 'Gin'. When a player gets 'Gin', he or she must show the cards to the other players and explain what the two groupings of the cards are. The groupings may be of similar triangles, same area, or same perimeter.

Components:
48 cards

65570.name: Goobles
65570.description:
Goobles is a game to help students identify and learn the relational structure of knowledge in a particular domain. Students have difficulty in connecting concepts and creating a sequence of concepts. This game will help students forge ideas about relationships and to build critical thinking skills.

There are two types of cards:

Category card: an umbrella concept (for example: Newton's Laws, Mechanics, Dynamics, Kinematics, etc.) that can be used to connect two sequences. There are two cards for each category.
Term card: representing a more atomic concept, such as length, mass, velocity, speed, etc. There are four cards for each term (to increase the possibility of chain building).




Each subsequent player either chooses one of his or her five cards to build a sequence or starts a new sequence and scores following:

5 points for playing a card with a strongly related concept.
2 points for playing a category card.
-1 point for starting a new sequence.
2 bonus points for playing a card that joins two sequences.




Components:
50 cards

65571.name: Go Reduce
65571.description:
Given a fraction, the player will be able to reduce the fraction to its lowest terms. The learner will then multiply the reduced fraction by 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, or 9 to produce an equivalent fraction.

The game design is similar to that of the children's game, "Go Fish.

If the player has pairs of equivalent fractions he/she can start their own "count" of pairs. If the player can find no matches he/she will ask any player by name, for an equivalent fraction. For example: "Adam, do you have an equivalent fraction to 1/2?"




If Adam does have the equivalent fraction, Adam must surrender his card. The player continues asking the others until one player has no match and will have to reply, "Go Reduce."

The player will then take a card from the face down pond. The next player is on his/her left.
The play continues until all cards are matched. If players run out of cards, the game has ended for them. They will have to wait until all players have played their hands.
The winner is the player with the most pairs of equivalent fractions.




Components:
48 cards

65572.name: Government Poker
65572.description:
Learners will be able to match the specific number of the Bill of Rights and the Amendments to the Constitution to their content.

Each player tries to pair the correct number card with its content card. Play continues until a player lays down all their cards as pairs of matching number and content cards and scores two points for a pair,plus two more points for a sequence of two pairs, or three points for a sequence of three pairs, etc.
Play continues until the one player reaches a 50 points.

Components:
68 cards

65573.name: Grocery Rummy
65573.description:
The players will be able to organize and budget for grocery shopping according to planned menus. They will attain mastery of monies calculation skills. In the affective domain, the students will acquire an understanding of how complex planning and budgeting can be when wants and needs meet prices and paychecks.

The object of the game is to get the Groceries needed for specified Menus within a predetermined budget. The teacher will determine the budget based on the number of Menus each student must "shop" for - approximately $12-$15 per Menu.
If the player/shopper has overspent or forgotten an item on the Menu, that amount is deducted from the player's "savings," i.e., score total. Likewise, if the player has money left over in the budget, that surplus is added to the player's score total. The game is over when a player reaches a predetermined score, e.g., $50. If a time limit is set instead, e.g. 20 min., the winner is the player with the highest score at the end of the period.

Components:
- The deck contains 72 cards:
- six different Menu cards,
- 54 Grocery cards (including generic, lower-priced alternatives to brand names),
- six Non-Food Grocery cards,
- three Coupon cards,
- three "1/2 Off" cards

65575.description:
One hundred giant elephants are running amok, but one tiny mouse has got their number! Roll the dice and move the mouse around the board, searching high and low for elephants that are either higher or lower than the number on your card. If you spot a mouse hiding on a card, shout Eeek!and grab the mouse figurine before it scampers away! You’ll need to have a memory like an elephant and be quick as a mouse to win!

Contents:
100 elephant cards
2 custom dice
1 mouse figurine
rules of play in English
rules of play in Spanish
65575.name: Hide and Eeek!

65579.name: K'Dak's Tower of Confusion and Camel Wash
65579.description:
You and your best buddy, Kaka, are two young dudes cruising the back streets of ancient Egypt looking for a cheap double-hump wash and blow dry for your camel, Phredd. Unfortunately, being somewhat shy of means (i.e., broke), you are unable to afford the more reputable establishments. Acting on Kaka’s dubious suggestion, you
head out to the edge of town to a place your mother told you never to go: the old, abandoned tower built by that nutcase, K’Dak. K’Dak was a washout from pyramid building school. He just could never get the pyramid concept straight. Big on the bottom and small on top. How is this hard? Anyway, his attempt at building a small summer
pyramid for the pharaoh ended up as a six-story, straight up and down tower. The pharaoh was not amused and K’Dak was banished from the community in disgrace. That should have been the end of it, but K’Dak had in mind one last futile gesture before he left. He returned to the tower, hid small amounts of gold throughout the structure and then set up a booby trap for anyone who tried to retrieve the gold. However, before he could spread a story of a fabulous treasure residing in his tower, he was run out of town by the authorities and never seen again. The pharaoh intended to condemn the place for demolition, but got distracted with a border war and K’Dak’s tower was largely
forgotten. And now, you and Kaka are heading to this questionable monument on the outside chance that there is something inside that you can barter for a camel makeover.

K’Dak’s Tower of Confusion and Camel Wash is a game of exploration. You and your opponent climb through an abandoned tower hoping to collect enough treasure in order to pay for a bath for Phredd. Things go just fine until one of you reaches the top layer, at which time the tower starts shaking itself apart. You then have to get out before the whole structure collapses on you while still finding enough treasure to make the expedition worthwhile.

65580.name: Űrkaland
65580.description: This is a Hungarian space strategy game created in the 80's. One of the players, Captain John Konig protects the valuable energy packages while the others trying to get those from him. To achieve this he has to stop the other players, who have to get over various obstacles such as meteoric zones, narrow pass-through gates. These obstacles form concentric circles, the attacking players start on the outside, and their goal is to get to the center, get the energy packets, and take one of them to the starting zone. The quickest one wins the game. Each of the attacking players as well as Captain John Konig are controlling four spaceships.

65581.description:
If you've ever read Belgian or French ligne claire adventure comics, then the artwork in this game will look very familiar to you. In fact, the spirit of the game itself comes across like one of those stories, with the players being adventurers in the early twentieth century who are entering an enormous Egyptian pyramid in order to discover the riches that lie in wait. Alas, the adventurers' presence sets off a series of 3,000-year-old traps and they become separated inside a lethal maze.

Turns out that the maze is of their own creation, though, as players take turns laying down tiles that show corridors, monsters, traps or equipment. They must reach a staircase exit in order to gain their freedom, possibly facing off against monsters while doing so and using the strengths of their four characteristics to survive.

NB: Currently only in French, Spanish and Italian
65581.name: Hamunaptra: Aventures dans la Grande Pyramide

65582.description:
The designers self-published a thousand copies of Regatta in 2008, and now Gigamic has picked up the game for wider distribution. To win, you must circle two buoys and cross the finish line with your wooden ship before anyone else, and to do that, on your turn you play one of five movement cards in your hand to scoot your boat across the waves. The game includes an additional, slightly more complicated way to play for when the five-year-olds go to bed.


Microbadge:
65582.name: Regatta

65583.name: Dragón (Número 16 - Dic 1994)
65583.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #16
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon (Issue 184 - Aug 1992) and Dungeon (Issue 26 - Nov 1990).
Summary:

ARTÍCULOS:

CORTES DE CORTESANOS
Un Rey necesita soldados, pero también diplomáticos, cocineros y hasta juglares.
MALOS, MUY MALOS
Un buen villano nunca morderá el polvo con facilidad, sobre todo si sigues estos consejos.
EL PNJ EN SIETE FRASES, por C.M. Cline
Convierte a los PNJ en gente de verdad sólo con siete simples frases
TU, OTRA VEZ!, por Scott Sheffield
Los peores enemigos son aquellos que no olvidan (y nunca se mueren).
EL CODIGO DE HONOR DEL MASTER, por John Setzer
Seis cosas que puedes hacer para mejorar tus partidas.
DONDE ESTABAS TU EN EL 94?, por Francisco José Campos y Laura Balestra
Completa información sobre la Gen Con 94 en España.

MÓDULOS:

TRES CAMELLOS Y UN TRINEO, por "Melchor Campos", "Gaspar Ibáñez" y "Baltasar Aceytuno", basado en una idea de "Nicolás Vigil" (módulo para RuneQuest para 3 personajes y el máster).
La verdadera historia de la Navidad en el Mundo Disco (y por que la celebren más bien poco).
GUARDAS DE CARAVANA, por Stephen J.Smith (aventura de D&D Expert, niveles 6-8)
¿Por qué se que los trabajos sencillos son siempre los que más se complican?

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Oigan! Oigan!, habla el dire.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Si tú nos escribes, nosotros te respondemos.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Aceptamos todo tipo de consultas, excepto las que versan sobre Hacienda.
+3 EN CARISMA
O cómo ensanchar tu círculo de amistades por el precio de un sello.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Las movidas roleras más sonadas del país.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Lo único que no controlan son las cotizaciones de Wall Street.
RUINAS Y PERGAMINOS
Una biblioteca más que ideal, para disfrutar entre partidas.
JAQUE MATE
Lo más nuevo, lo más atractivo, lo más interesante del mes.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Adornan la partida, se pueden coleccionar y pintar.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Del disquette al CD-ROM, todo puede iluminar nuestro ocio.
LA TIRADA FINAL
Reflexión, despedida y cierre.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa
Dragon (Issue 184 - Aug 1992) y Dungeon (Issue 26 - Nov 1990).)

65586.name: Splotch
65586.description:
Splotch is played on a 4x4 hexagonal board.There are a sufficient number of black,white and red stackable stones off-board.These stones are shared by both players.
On each turn,each player drops a stone of either color on a cell.
After each drop,the adjacent cells are adjusted.
After the adjust,the player captures any stack with all the three colors.
Wins the player that makes 10 captures.

65587.name: Der HeidelBÄR: Kuh-Erweiterung
boardgameexpansion: Der HeidelBÄR
65587.description:
This is an 20 card expansion pack to the game "Der HeidelBÄR".

As in the base game, players try to explain words from a card. In the base game, all words include a syllable that sounds like the german "Bär" (bear), while in the expansion there is always a "Kuh" (Cow) hidden somewhere in the word.

Players can use only up to six words to explain the word on the card, and the first two words of the explanation must always be "This cow ..." or "My cow ...", so you only have four words left.

65588.name: Stucco
65588.description:
This game is played with 32 cards from a standard deck of cards, with cyclic ranking AKQJ10987. Both players are dealt 16 cards (therefore they know the cards of the other player).

To decide who starts, both players select a card from their hand and reveal them simultaneously. If both cards are the same colour (red or black) then non-dealer starts; if different, dealer starts. The starter's card is left face up on the table as the first card played and the other is returned to its player's hand. The non-starter then plays the second card to the spread, and play thereafter alternates.

A player in his turn can play a card which is either the next higher card of the same suit, or the next lower card of the other suit of the same colour, or a card of the same rank but opposite colour. If the player does not have any of these, has to pass. The play continues until nobody can play any more cards. Whoever plays the last card scores 1 point for each card he played, multiplied by the number of cards he played consecutively on the last turn.

65589.name: Tantony
65589.description:
This game is played with a standard deck of cards. With four players, the game consist of four deals, but cards are actually dealt only at the beginning. After each round players have 13 cards and use them in the next round.

Tricks are played and the highest card in the suit led wins; the value of the trick is the smallest card in that suit. However, winner of the trick can either keep it, or give it to anyone else. Everybode can get at most three tricks, this way they have 12 cards after 12 tricks. The winner of the last trick scores for it, but every player keeps the last card. Then a new round starts.

Each player leads the first trick once in the four round. However, a game ends in an earlier "sudden death" win if one side has reached 60 at the end of the first hand, 120 at the end of the second, or 180 at the end of the third.

boardgamehonor: 2010 Fairplay À la carte Winner
65590.description: In Himmel, A... und Zwirn! players take turns playing one card at a time, with the card being higher than what's out there but lower than the target card. The gap of playable cards narrows quickly, and if you can't fill the gap, you have to take the cards and pile up the negative points. The theme is, well...wildlife posteriors.
65590.name: Bumbesi

65592.name: Dragon's Ordeal
65592.description: A fantasy adventure game played on a modular board created from various of locations. The goal is to kill Dragon hidden at end of board. On the way there will be many traps and monsters to defeat. During game play each player will develop their characters, discover new areas and fight against monsters drafted from story cards for spells, equipment and powerful artifacts!

65594.name: Dragón (Número 17 - Ene 1995)
65594.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #17
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon #208, Dragon (Issue 209 - Sep 1994), #210, and Dungeon (Issue 50 - Nov 1994).
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

GEAS: EL JUEGO DE CARTAS VISTANI, por Stephen Fabian
Los gitanos de Ravenloft lo juegan con deleite, y ahora tú también puedes hacerlo.
MOTIVATE, por Gregory Gliedman
Una forma de darle un empujoncito hacia la aventura a tus personajes jugadores.
EN DEFENSA DE LOS REINOS, por Allen Varney
Reglas opcionales y atrevidas variantes para jugar al Spellfire.
UN MOSTRUO DE TRADICION CLASICA, por Steve Berman
Recuperamos un viejo mito griego para La Llamada de Cthulhu.
EX LIBRIS, por James R. Colier
Quien tiene un libro, tiene un tesoro, poco más o menos.
GUARNICIONERIA MAGICA, por Gordon R. Menzies
Lo que nunca encontrarás para tu caballo en una tienda de efectos hípicos.
LAS MIL Y UNA CARAS DE LOS NO-MUERTOS, por Theron Martin
Crea los no-muetros más pavorosos que puedas imaginar para Dark Sun.
MÁS SOBRE LA GEN CON 94, por Francisco José Campos
Algunas cosillas que merecen la pena y se nos quedaron colgadas por la premura del último número.

MÓDULOS:

LA MALDICION DE STELLA MARIS, por Ted James (módulo para AD&D, niveles 7 o 2-4)
Un pequeño viaje por mar es lo más indicado para combatir la melancolía ¿o no?
AQUÍ NO HAY PLAYA?, por Willie Walsh (aventura de AD&D Expert, niveles 1-2)
Llévate el bronceador, la toalla, y una buena espada, por si acaso.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Fanfarria triunfal, que habla nuestro dire.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Todo aquello que queréis compartir con nostros.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Se aclaran puntos oscuros, se explican reglas y se imparte sabiduría concentrada.
+3 EN CARISMA
Desde tiernos requiebros a desesperadas llamadas de auxilio.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
"Baedeker" DRAGON en todo el buen rollo del rol.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Animo, que la economía y el consumo se están recuperando.
RUINAS Y PERGAMINOS
Para aquellos que no sólo quieren leer libros de reglas.
JAQUE MATE
Recomendaciones del "chef" para partidas con fundamento.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Además, ahora nos hemos empeñado en que aprendáis a pintar.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Tecnologías recién salidas del horno, creadas para la diversión.
LA TIRADA FINAL
La vida, el universo, los dados de ocho y todo lo demás...

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon #208, Dragon (Issue 209 - Sep 1994), #210, y Dungeon (Issue 50 - Nov 1994)).

65595.description: Players are mice who are tossing paintballs at cats, with the paintballs being represented by colored sticks. When someone knocks over one or more sticks with the wooden cheese disk pictured below, players must race to locate the cat covered with those colours and grab the tile before anyone else.
65595.name: Mouse-Party
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGTG 110 - All About the Easy Play games (with David Arnott)

65596.name: Bauernschlau
65596.description:
Players take turns selecting plots of land from a 6x6 grid. As soon as a row or column is completed, points are awarded to the player owning the most land.

This game has nothing to do with Bauernschlau.

boardgamehonor: 2010 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Nominee
2010 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
2010 Spiel des Jahres Kinderspiel Nominee
65599.description:
The farm animals are going on holiday! But alas, the farmer has messed up everyone's tickets and it's not clear to him who's going where. Thankfully you and your fellow players can lend a hand, but the sorting challenge won't be easy. When you're the active player, you must wear glasses that cover your eyes; the player to your left then draws a task card and places the animal pictured on it in your hand. You try to identify the animal by touch and announce what animal you think you hold. The player then explains your task and you try to perform it, such as placing the animal in the correct location (as marked on the gameboard that game). You can feel the gameboard and other animals already in place, but knock any of them over and your turn ends immediately.

Other tasks include removing the proper animal from the gameboard and stating how many are currently on the board. The animals on parade change nearly every turn, so you'll need sensitive fingers and a good memory if you want to help them see the world...

Available in English, German, French, Dutch, Spanish, Italian.
65599.name: Turi-Tour

65600.name: Blocks City
65600.description: You would think being a real-estate developer in this city would be easy, since there are only three building codes in the city. But nooo, you have to deal with the other real-estate developers trying to take over your buildings, an Arsonist that would love to see one of your buildings burn to the ground and that pesky Building Inspector that just seems to either waste your time or make you redo the work you have already done. But despite all that, it is worth it once you get that nice tall building overlooking the park completed. Blocks City is a three dimensional game. Players use their blocks to build the city, your goal is to score the most prestige points at the end of the game.

65601.name: Drachenland
65601.description:
Players command the forces of one of the Clans at the island of Drachenland (Dragonland), trying to dominate the island by using different troop types like Heavy infantry, Light cavalry etc., lead by a clan leader and a clan sorcerer. An unbesieged clan castle yields income to (re-)build units.
Each clan has also his own mythical creature (e.g. the Bear Clan a Bear), which can be summoned at its sanctuary for support.

The island is represented by a hex grid with terrain and location features, the counters have to be mounted and cut, all components are in black and white on paper only.
Drachenland was published in the German Fantasy Pulp Magazine Mythor in
the Magazines No. 150 to 156, each containing a double page with map
parts and counters on one side and rules (beside with some
advertisements) on the other. Published in six parts the second one was
published corrupted, so in No. 156 part two was published again, this time correctly.

The Drachenland novel consists of Magazine No. 150 to 162.

65602.name: Trail of Cthulhu: Player's Guide
65602.description:
Trail of Cthulhu is a complete game of investigative horror set in the 1930s based on the work of HP Lovecraft. The game uses an adapted version of the Gumshoe system which offers a laser-like focus on investigation, with characters driven to explore and investigate, even at the expense of their own health and sanity.

The Trail of Cthulhu Player's Guide is all the player's stuff from GUMSHOE Trail of Cthulhu, including the complete Trail GUMSHOE system, character creation, equipment lists, player tips and forms. It weighs in at 99 pages, compared with the potent 248 Ken Hite-ened pages of the full Trail.

65603.name: Grips Champion
65603.description:
Train your memory, so that you can store data, lists, numbers and names easily and permanently. You will be astonished, how fast you are able to achieve true master achievements and this easy, but effectively. Profit from a good memory at your job, at school as well as in the everyday life. The game contains different variants with different levels of difficulty. (Text from the box)

Components: 1 two sided board, 100 Memory-Cards, 4 Pawns, 4 Tokens, 1 six sided Die, Rules

65604.name: Battle Born
65604.description:
(User Summary for Revised Second Edition, compiled from several chapters):

One thousand years in the future, the Tetra-League (an alliance between humans and three alien races) is torn by internal rivalry and threatened by external forces too numerous to mention. Tetra-League citizens are free from the burden of aging, thanks to mortality reduction drugs, but they are also free from the burden of choice; a weapon known as the Pacification Virus rendered them unable to commit acts of aggression or confrontation. Many citizens cannot even fend for themselves, and must live in sprawling facilities tended by robot caretakers. The virus mutated quickly, and now passes from mother to child. Everyone is infected. There is no cure. But some are spared....

Players take the roles of Immunes, those one-in-a-million Tetra-League citizens who are unaffected by the Pacification Virus. Some Immunes serve (willingly or otherwise) as soldiers in the Battle Born, a branch of MACE, the Tetra-League's "Military Assault and Combat Expedition" force (or, as the squads are fond of saying, "Most Anyone Conscious and Expendable"). A Battle Born trooper wears special powered armor called an "EE" Suit, which is so effective it can destroy just about anything, except someone else in an EE Suit. This gives rise to a problem - soldiers that want to survive must learn to use their armor in ways that go beyond the suit’s design....

This book includes sections on character generation, skills and equipment, advancement, psionics, starships, ship-to-ship combat, introductory encounters, background material for the Era Ten campaign setting, and optional "Quick-and-Dirty" systems designed to make running mass-combat planetary actions and orbital assaults easier and more enjoyable. Rules expansions and additional material can be found in the Guardians of Sol RPG, the pages of Space Gamer Magazine, and on Better Games' Web site.

Battle Born can be played alone, or as a supplement to enhance any Sci-Fi game system.

65606.name: Gypo Logging Board Game
65606.description:
This is a roll-and-move game in the style of Monopoly. It has an "Inner Board", similar to Careers, where you roll only one die, rather than two. It has no well-defined end-game conditions: simply play for a set period of time and then total up your assets (cash, businesses and equipment), with the win going to the player with the highest total value.

From the back of the box:

Between the 1930's and late 80's was the heyday of the Gypo Logger. This was an era when a man, with very little or no formal education could get very rich in a short time, with a lot of backbreaking work, some good luck and with a highball crew working for him. Many more Gypo loggers also went broke in their ventures due to poor planning, unforeseen expenses, plain old 'bad luck' and a multitude of pitfalls which this game only touches the surface of. The term 'Gypo' refers to "haywire" or make do methods that are not necessarily proper--in other words lots of duct tape and haywire is holding everything together and you’re probably not using the right machine or tool anyway but somehow you're still getting the wood out.

65607.name: Radio Flash
65607.description:
The game comes with a spinner that matches Morse code signals. Each Radio Flash spin results in a code which causes different things to happen during your voyage. i.e. roll the letter k (-.-) and be subjected to a blizzard that requires you to go back 2 spaces. Some squares have 2 letters in the codes which have differing effects. J(.---)Q(--.-) results in, on the next spin requiring you to change course and take the Western Course via Cook and Fiji Islands.

You move your ship from port beginning in Bermuda, to the North Pole by either the Western or Eastern route. These routes can go all around the world.

To win the player must spin exactly enough to reach the North Pole.

65608.name: GamesMaster International (Issue 5 - Dec 1990)
rpgissuearticle: Smoking Guns can Seriously Damage Your Health
65608.description:
From the Cover:

CYBER SPECIAL!

Exclusive: Cyberpunk Guru William Gibson Speaks Out
Cyberpunk 2020 The Second Edition
New Weapons for Night City Folk




Exclusive:

AD&D Origins Tournament Scenario




Reviewed: Buck Rogers, Torg, Rifts, Twilight: 2000 - The Second Edition, and more!

65609.name: Sudoku: Tactics
65609.description:
In Sudoku: Tactics, players take turns drawing 1-5 number tiles and place them in any order to complete rows, columns and 3x3 sub-grids following the rules of Sudoku. Each completion scores one point, and the tiles in the completed areas are removed and returned to the tile pile. If a player is unable to legally place a number, a "Sudoku Jam" occurs; all tiles with that number are returned to the pile and the previous player scores a point. Since the board is never entirely filled up, the game is played to an arbitrary number of points or time limit agreed to in advance.

Similar to other Blue Panther products, the box, nine-piece board, scoreboard and 81 tiles are all laser-etched wood. The board pieces fit together like a jigsaw puzzle. The game also comes with a printed paper instruction sheet and five pairs of plastic cubes to mark player scores.

65610.name: Dragón (Número 18 - Mar 1995)
65610.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #18
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon #211, #212 and Dungeon #51.
Summary:

ARTÍCULOS:

LA ECOLOGIA DEL DUNGEON, por Buck Daeson Holmes
Hay quien dice que visto un dungeon, vistos todos. Te ofrecemos ideas para dar al traste con esta afirmación.
ECHANDO MANOS EN LOS LIBROS, por Eric R. Noah
El JdR de fantasía deriva directamente a la literatura pero ¿cómo hacer que ambos se parezcan lo más posible?
ATENGANSE A LAS CONSECUENCIAS, por Renee Stern
El universo de juego siempre gira, con los PJ o sin ellos. Y todo lo que hagan tiene su contrapartida.
HONGOS DE BAJOSCURIDAD, por Chris PerryPo
Micología fantástica para aventureros aficionados a las setas.
TRUCOS DEL OFICIO, por George T.Young
El buen máster no "arbitra una partida": crea una narración realmente interactiva.

MÓDULOS:

LA HABITACIÓN DE NADIE, por Jeff Crook (módulo para AD&D, niveles 4-5)
Si eres miedoso y aprensivo, no entres en esta habitación, donde pasan cosas muy raras.
HIJOS DE LOS BREZALES, por Carlos González (módulo para Universo: El juego de rol multiambiental)
Una de romanos, pero en serio: nada de trompazos estilo Astérix.
VIAJE AL CENTRO DEL MUNDO, por Chris Hind (módulo para AD&D, niveles 8-10)
Si encuentras los elefantes, puedes hacerte rico. Y si no ¿qué?

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
La cualificada opinión de nuestro excelso Director.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Opiniones de todos los gustos y colores sobre nuestra afición favorita.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Plantea las dudas que te quitan el sueño, y nosotros te las responderemos con la mejor intención.
+3 EN CARISMA
Un especie de club de relaciones y amistades, pero para jugadores de rol.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Los que se mueven, los que organizan cosas, los que tienen algo que decir.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Una buena manera de completar tu ludoteca a buen precio.
RUINAS Y PERGAMINOS
La biblioteca que no puede faltar al lado de tus reglamentos.
JAQUE MATE
Ultimas novedades llegadas hasta nuestra redacción.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Directamente des de la Gran Bretaña, las miniaturas pasman al aficionado.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
El lado humano y divertido de los videojuegos más actuales.
LA TIRADA FINAL
Opiniones de un máster del montón metido a redactor jefe.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon #211, #212 y Dungeon #51).

boardgamehonor: 2011 Golden Geek Best Party Board Game Nominee
65611.description:
Serving Cthulhu is fun... except for all those other cultists out to get you. So get them first!

Cthulhu Dice lets you drive your rivals mad... Very, very quickly. Players take turns rolling the big, beautiful, custom 12-sided die, embossed with tentacles, Elder Signs, and more. Destroy your opponents' sanity! Better yet, steal it. But watch out for Cthulhu – when he comes up, he takes sanity from everyone! Eighteen glass Sanity marbles are included. Lose all your marbles and you're mad. The last sane cultist wins... Unless everyone goes mad together. Then Cthulhu wins!
boardgameversion: Spanish edition: Lime green die/black ink
Steve Jackson Black Die and Green Ink edition
Steve Jackson Dark Red Die and Gold Ink edition
Steve Jackson Green Die and Yellow Ink edition
Steve Jackson Purple Die and Green Ink edition
Steve Jackson Sparkly Pink Die and White Ink edition
Steve Jackson Yellow Die and Black Ink edition
65611.name: Cthulhu Dice

65612.name: Dragón (Número 19 - May 1995)
65612.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #19
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon (Issue 209 - Sep 1994), #212, Dragon (Issue 215 - Mar 1995) and Dungeon #52.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

NO HAY MAL QUE POR BIEN VENGA, por Jonathan M.Richards
Cómo darle la vuelta para darle provecho a una de las plagas de la fantasía medieval: las maldiciones.
LA PARTIDA DE LOS PRINCIPIANTES, por John Nephew
Aprende A interesar en el rol a los jugadores que se inician contigo.
JUGANDO CON ESTILO, por Thomas M.Kane
En el rol hay diverasa maneras de jugar, y cada una tiene sus aspectos atractivos.
ELIGE TUS ARMAS, por Bruce Nesmith y Francisco José Campos
Dos puntos de vista y dos estrategias a la hora de preparar barajas de Spellfire.
LA FABRICA DE GOLEMS, por Terry Dykstra
Tres criaturas animadas para añadir en tu Compendio de Monstruos.

MÓDULOS:

BIENVENIDOS A CRIPTHOGAR, por Samuel Heath (módulo para AD&D, niveles 1-3)
¿Qué se puede hacer cuando tu enemigo es "inteligente"?
THE LONG TOMORROW, por Francsico José Campos, Ricard Ibáñez y Miguel Aceytuno (aventura de Shadowrun)
Incluso en el año 2052, los detectives siguen estando bastante mal pagados.
EL HOMBRE RISUEÑO, por Paul Culotta (aventura breve de AD&D, niveles 5-9)
El sentido del humor propio de las brumosas tierras de Ravenoft te helará la sangre en las venas.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
El dire nos da la bienvenida a esta vuestra revista.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Quien tenga algo que decir que lo diga: aquí se escucha a todo el mundo.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Si tu juego favorito te plantea problemas, nosotros te los solucionamos.
+3 EN CARISMA
La gente que no quiere jugar sola es nuestra principal clientela.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Las iniciativas que vosotros proponéis para el engrandecimiento de la afición.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Las ofertas y demandas más irresistibles.
CONCURSO ROL CRUSADERS
Y por fin, la lista de los afortunados ganadores de uno de estos maravillosos juegos de ordenador.
RUINAS Y PERGAMINOS
En clase de literatura, estos libros nunca serán de lectura obligatoria, a pesar de esta muy bien.
JAQUE MATE
Infórmate de todo lo que es nuevo e interesante.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
El fascinante mundillo de la figura de fantasía, a tu alcance.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Una imparable cerrera tecnológica dedicada en exclusiva a la diversión.
LA TIRADA FINAL
Una pantalla de master abierta a todos los jugadores.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon (Issue 209 - Sep 1994), #212, Dragon (Issue 215 - Mar 1995) y Dungeon #52).

65613.name: Dragón (Número 20 - Jul 1995)
65613.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #20
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon #216 and Dungeon #52.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

LOS SENDEROS DEL PODER, por Wolfgang Baur y Steve Kurtz
Todo un nuevo sistema de magia para epatar a tus jugadores de AD&D.
DIOS MIO, ESTOY HERIDO!, por Rich Baker y Skip Williams
Tabla de críticos que , sin duda, hará mucho más dramáticos tus combates de Advanced.
KARAOKE PARA BARDOS
Famosas canciones que tienen bastante que ver con nuestras aficiones, para que déis la nota en vuestra próxima reunión.
GEN CON 95: YA ESTAMOS EN MARCHA!, por Joaquim Dorca
Este año, con algo más de premura y a cinco meses vista, empezamos a informar sobre el evento de Rol Más Grande Jamás Montado.

MÓDULOS:

ESPIRITUS EN LA TORMENTA, adaptado por Michael Selinker (módulo para AD&D, niveles 9-10)
Hill, el bardo de Strafford Up Avon, estaría muy satisfecho con esta versión de una de sus más famosas obras.
OPERACIÓN CHISMOSO, por Juan Carlos Herreros (módulo para comandos de guerra)
La mejor manera de celebrar el 50 aniversario del fin de la guerra mundial es retroceder en el tiempo y añadir tu granito de arena para lograr la victoria.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
El dire inaugura una nueva colección de dragones.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Grandes o pequeñas inquietudes sobre el mundo de rol.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
A preguntas concisas, respuestas concretas.
+3 EN CARISMA
Por un mundo más humano y más practicante del JdR,
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Desde jornadas a fanzines, pasando por nuevos clubs y asociaciones.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Diríase que un mercadillo, pero con mucho más lustre.
RUINAS Y PERGAMINOS
Cuando la magia se convierte en letra impresa.
JAQUE MATE
Novedades que llegan a raudales.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Materiales que dan forma a sueños fantásticos.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Maquinas imponentes parta la diversión hogareña.
LA TIRADA FINAL
Y con un par de comentarios más o menos atinados, damos fin a esta entrega.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon #216 y Dungeon #52).

65614.name: Dragón (Número 21 - Sep 1995)
65614.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #21
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon #216, #217, #218 and Dungeon #54.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

OFICIOS Y BENEFICIOS
A parte de las consabidas monedas de oro ¿qué de otras formas se puede recompensar a los nunca bien ponderados PJ?
UNA OPORTUNIDAD UNICA, por Steven Miller
Adquiera por un precio irrisorio uno de los maravillosos lotes de objetos mágicos de Bargle el Infame. ¡No deje escapar esta increíble oferta!
DOS CABEZAS PIENSAN MEJOR QUE UNA, por Joshua Siegel
Las partidas con dos másters son más organizadas. Que no es poco.
INTRIGAS DE DRAGÓN, por Gregory W.Detwiler
Un buen dragón no se limita a pelear cuando le invaden el cubil. Son mucho más listos de lo que creemos.
LA VERDADERA NATURALEZA DEL MAL, por Michael T.Kuciak
Los villanos realmente odiosos son lo que más atraen a los jugadores. Aunque sea para rebanarles el gaznate…
GEN CON 94: ROLEROS A ESCENA!, por Laura Balestra
Últimas novedades, logros e informaciones fidedignas acerca de esta cita ineludible que tenemos todos en noviembre.

MÓDULOS:

TIERRA IMPIA, por Dan De Fazio (módulo para AD&D, niveles 2-4)
¿Quién esta enterrado a las afueras del monasterio?
EL ULTIMO DRAGON (MAGICO MUNDO DE COLORES), por Francisco José Campos y Ricard Ibáñez (módulo para Fanhunter, el JdR picodecadente)
Una misión suicida de importancia subliminal, sólo para narizotas con agallas y poco cerebro.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
¿con qué "rara draconis" apoyará el dire sus doctas palabras?
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Sea bienvenido todo aquel que tenga algo que decir.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Dioses, si, aunque a veces parezcan bastante humanos.
+3 EN CARISMA
Si estás más agobiado que Raistlin en un concurso de chistes, será porque tu quieres.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Gente inquieta de todos los rincones del reino.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
No, a Tasselhoftt no le dejamos que venda nada, por si las moscas.
RUINAS Y PERGAMINOS
Leer es una de las aventuras más maravillosas.
JAQUE MATE
Lo que llena nuestro corazón y hace temblar a nuestro bolsillo.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Aplicando las más modernas técnicas a la fantasía típica.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
De mano en el teclado y de cara al monitor ¿Quién dijo que era un castigo?
LA TIRADA FINAL
Descabello filosófico para acabar la lidia del saurio.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon #216, #217, #218 y Dungeon #54).

65615.name: The Habit Challenge
65615.description:
The players shall be able to become more aware of what constitutes both good and bad habits.

Players must try to get as many Good Habit cards as possible and discard all Bad Hait cards. The game ends when one player acquires four Good Habit cards in one category and three in the other, with no Bad Habit cards. The winning player then announces, "Good Habits," he shows his seven winning cards, and the game is over.

Components:
56 cards in 2 categories: Character or Hygiene + 4 Good Karma bonus cards

65616.name: HeadGames
65616.description:
This is educational cardgame for veterinary students.

Game play is similar to Rummy. The object of the game is to make melds of related cards to earn points and to be the first to reach 500 points.

Components:
52 cards

65617.name: Galaxy of Intrigue
65617.description:
From the back of the book:

"'Many Bothans died to bring us this information.'
While war rages on throughout the galaxy, a more subtle conflict is taking place in the shadows: a war of intrigue. Secrets are whispered in dark corners, bribes pass through corrupt hands, and saboteurs and assassins directly attack the resources and allies of their enemies. A campaign full of intrigue is a campaign full of mystery, where as one layer of the plot is revealed, so are three more mysteries whose true meaning have yet to be discovered.

Galaxy of Intrigue presents a variety of options for both players and gamemasters, including:

New talents, feats, weapons and equipment for nobles, spies, and saboteurs.
A complete rules set for skill challenges.
Guidelines for running campaigns full of intrigue.
An all new planet that boils over with secrecy and mystery.
New campaign content, including a full-length adventure."

65618.name: Dragón (Número 22 - Oct 1995)
65618.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #22
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon #219 and Dungeon #54.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

TAJOS Y ESTOCADAS, por Chris Williams
Las aventuras de capa y espada, con todos sus atractivos, pueden ser adaptadas a tu sistema de rol favorito.
PIRATAS, SICARIOS Y DEMAS BERGANTES, por James R.Collier
Nuevas tablas para seguidores de PJ de niveles altos, incluyendo líderes y tropas de elite.
CORRE!, por Daniel Mark Vyleta
Cómo simular esas ocasiones en las que hay que decir ¡Pies, para qué os quiero!
ESPECIAL GEN CON 95: PROGRAMA OFICIAL
DRAGON se convierte en el más selecto programa de actividades con el que puedes acudir a la Gran convención de rol.
BLOOD WAR: REGLAMENTOS EN CASTELLANO, por Joaquim Dorca
Si quieres saber cómo funciona uno de los juegos de cartas de más éxito en EEUU, aquí tienes las reglas en castellano.

MÓDULOS:

LOS AMIGOS DE TETHYR, por David Howery (módulo para AD&D, niveles 6-8)
Si Spielberg jugase a rol, Parque Jurasico podía haber sido muy parecido a esto.
BANDERA ROJA, por Ricard Ibáñez (módulo para Piratas! De 4 a 6 jugadores de escasa experiencia)
No todos los piratas son "honrados" asesinos que se dedican a lo suyo , que se roban y saquean...

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
¿con qué "rara draconis" apoyará el dire sus doctas palabras?
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Desde pequeñas dudas metafísicas a las más cáusticas cuestiones.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Si los clérigos les dan conjuros, a nosotros que por lo menos nos den consejo.
+3 EN CARISMA
Para Robinsones roleros y otras gentes con apuros lúdicos.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Trompeteos, noticias de buena tinta y pregones puestos al día.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Para los que quieren comprar y vender, pasando de las cotizaciones de la Bolsa.
JAQUE MATE
Vamos de descubierta por las tiendas del sector.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Las figuras que no pueden faltar en esa partida tan increíble que estás montando.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
El rol que cambia los dados por los procesadores matemáticos.
LA TIRADA FINAL
¿Habéis cerrado el gas y dejado comida al gato¿ Pues nos vamos.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon #219y Dungeon #54).

65619.name: La Historia de México
65619.description:
The players will be able to review the major events in Mexican history and the order in which the events occurred. Non-native Spanish speakers will also practice understanding written Spanish. They should also be able to enjoy this activity and enjoy working within the group of players.

The object of the game is to get two runs of three and four cards representing the sequential order of the events from Mexican history.

components:
52 cards

65620.name: Dragón (Número 24 - Abr 1996)
65620.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #24
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon (Issue 224 - Dec 1995), Dungeon #53 and #55.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

GUÍA DEL DISEÑADOR DE CASTILLOS PARA VÉRSELAS CON LA MAGIA, por Jeffrey Allen Paul
En un mundo de fantasía medieval, los asedios son mucho más feroces gracias a la intervención de la magia. Sepamos entonces como defendernos de ella.
EL SUEÑO ETERNO, por Steven Schend
El diseño de una buena tumbas fundamental: se supone que su inquilino quiere estar tranquilo durante mucho tiempo, y hay que evitarle todas las incomodidades posibles.
LA HISTORIA DEL CETRO, por Skip Williams
La legendaria Vara de Siete Partes es uno de los artefactos más famosos y a la vez menos comprendidos de todos los de AD&D. También posee una de las historias más extensas y pintorescas.
RPGA: LA HERMANDAD UNIVERSLA DEL ROL
Conoce que es el Role Playing Game Association, o lo que es lo mismo, la sociedad internacional de jugadores de rol más importante del mundo.

MÓDULOS:
EL SEPULCRO DE CLARSHH, por Willie Walsh (módulo para AD&D, para 5 a 6 jugadores de nivel 1)
Alguien o algo malvado acecha en el interior de las catacumbas.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Nuestro Director sale de su cubil para disertar sobre lo humano, lo divino y lo rolero.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Cartas que no son comunes, ni infrecuentes, ni raras.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Una pregunta bien hecha siempre merece una respuesta pronto.
+3 EN CARISMA
Si fuera tan fácil como sacar la puntuación requerida con los dados, no harían falta secciones como ésta.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Llamamientos, avisos, toques y contactos a nivel de todo el reino.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
¿Y cómo me encontró? ¡Pues mirando en el Zoco, caramba!
JAQUE MATE
Pon un reglamento de rol en tu vida: no te pesará.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Para pintar, para coleccionar o simplemente para hacer bonito.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
La diversión a través de un monitor de 14 pulgadas.
LA TIRADA FINAL
¿Habéis dado de comer al Kobold? Pues nos vamos…

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon (Issue 224 - Dec 1995), Dungeon #53 y #55).

65621.name: Dragón (Número 25 - Jul 1996)
65621.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #25
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon (Issue 228 - Apr 1996) and Dungeon #58.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

JUNGLAS DE VERDAD, por Gregory Detwiler
Olvídate de las películas de Tarzán. Déjanos hablarte de lo que es hacer una campaña en una jungla de verdad.
AVENTURAS URBANAS, por Paul F.Culotta
Más tarde o más temprano vas a tener que vértelas con una campaña de ambiente urbano, así que más vale que te vayas preparando.
CAMPAÑA EN ATHALANTAN, por Ed Greenwood
¿Cómo eran los reinos cuando Elmister era joven? Aventúrate a entrar en el Reino de Athalantan, para averiguarlo.

MÓDULOS:

EL FANTASMA DE LA COLINA, por Samuel Heath (módulo para AD&D, nivel 1-4)
La historia habla del rescate de un rey, medido en plata. Pero, ¿qué espíritu inquieto mora en esas colinas?
CAVEAT EMPTOR, por Ted Zubich (módulo de AD&D, niveles 3-6 con un total de 18)
A veces, uno debe realmente temer el hacerle una visita al dentista.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Nuestro Director sale de su cubil para disertar sobre lo humano, lo divino y lo rolero.

EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
Llamamientos, avisos, toques y contactos a nivel de todo el reino.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
¿Y cómo me encontró? ¡Pues mirando en el Zoco, caramba!
JAQUE MATE
Pon un reglamento de rol en tu vida: no te pesará.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Para pintar, para coleccionar o simplemente para hacer bonito.
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
La diversión a través de un monitor de 14 pulgadas.
LA TIRADA FINAL
¿Habéis dado de comer al Kobold? Pues nos vamos.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon (Issue 228 - Apr 1996) y Dungeon #58).

65622.name: Dragón (Número 26 - Nov 1996)
65622.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #26
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon (Issue 230 - Jun 1996), #231 and Dungeon #59.
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

MATADRAGONES, por Wolfgang Baur
Se necesita ser muy macho para ser uno de los matadragones.
DRAGONES DE LEYENDA, por John D. Rateliff
Desde Fafnir hasta Smaug, los dragones de la fantasía van de lo temible a lo absurdo.
MAESTRO DE LADRONES, por Kart Garrison.
Cuando eres el mejor ¿cómo puedes mejorar?
EL LADRON QUE SURGIO DEL FRIO, Por Renné Stern
¡Harto de robar?¿Cansado de huir de la Ley? Bueno, cuando no puedes vencerlos...
LA RPGA, POR FIN EN ESPAÑA
Llega a nuestro país el mejore de los clubes para jugadores de rol.

MÓDULOS:

LA MALDICION DE UNA MADRE, por John Guzzetta (módulo para AD&D, nivel 3-5 con un total de 16 niveles)
El acontecimiento puede ser fausto, si la maldición puede ser evitada a tiempo.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Nuestro Director sale de su cubil para disertar sobre lo humano, lo divino y lo rolero.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Cartas que no son comunes, ni infrecuentes, ni raras.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES

+3 EN CARISMA
Si fuera tan fácil como sacar la puntuación requerida con los dados, no harían falta secciones como ésta.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE

BYTES Y MAZMORRAS

LA TIRADA FINAL
¿Habéis dado de comer al Kobold? Pues nos vamos.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon (Issue 230 - Jun 1996), #231 y Dungeon #59).

65623.name: Dragón (Número 27 - Ene 1997)
65623.description:
Spanish Dragón Magazine Issue #27
Some articles published in this journal have been taken from the English magazine Dragon (Issue 232 - Aug 1996), Dragon (Issue 233 - Sep 1996), #234 and Dungeon (Issue 62 - Nov 1996).
Summary in spanish:

ARTÍCULOS:

ASÍ FUE LA GEN CON 96, por Joaquim Dorca
El relato de las muchas cosas acontecidas durante la tercera edición de la reina de las convenciones de rol.
RUIDO DE ESPADAS, por Gregory W.Detwiler
A veces es precisa una demostración de fuerza para poder seguir adelante.
UNA VISITA A LA CORTE, por Larry Granato
Tarde o temprano hay que sacar la armadura de los domingos e irse alternar con la nobleza en la capital del reino.
MAESTRÍA DEL DM, por Keith Strohm
En casi todas las partidas, los verdaderos protagonistas son los personajes no jugadores.
EL LIBRO DE LAS ALMAS, por Robert S.Mullin
No te molestes en buscarlo en la biblioteca de tu barrio, porque seguramente no lo tienen.

MÓDULOS:

EL GUARDAESPALDAS DE ESMERALDA, por Paul F. Cullota (módulo para AD&D, nivel 6-9)
No, ésta no es la Esmeralda de Diseny, pero la diversión está asegurada.
EL FANTASMA DE LA CASA DE LA VIUDA DE SMITHER, por John Baichtal (módulo para AD&D, nivel 1-3)
Un sitio muy interesante para pernoctar, si no te asustas fácilmente, claro está.
SUELTOS POR LAS CALLES, por Jason Peck (módulo para AD&D, nivel 1-3)
Los chicos han vuelto a la ciudad, así que mejor quítate de en medio.

OTRAS SECCIONES PERMANENTES:

EL RUGIDO DEL DRAGÓN
Una reflexion serena sobre el mundo del rol y sus aledaños, a cargo de nuestro director.
PLUMAS ENVENENADAS
Las opiniones, alabanzas, varapalos y pareceres de los lectores de DRAGON.
EL ORÁCULO DE LOS DIOSES
Si alguna duda te corroe, impidiendo el normal desarrollo de la partida, pregúntales a los dioses.
+3 EN CARISMA
La pócima infalible para mejorar tus relaciones públicas.
EL HERALDO DE LA CORTE
El anuncio solemne de lo que se ha celebrado o se ha de celebrar.
EL ZONO DE LANKHMAR
Sección permanente de ofertas y rebajas. Sólo has fin de existencias.
JAQUE MATE
Libros y juegos que aún no han tenido tiempo de criar polvo en la estantería.
CON PIES DE PLOMO
Esculturas minimalistas para amantes del arte fantástico
BYTES Y MAZMORRAS
Nuestro otro compañero de juego: el ordenador.
LA TIRADA FINAL
Después de esto, por desgracia, sólo la contraportada nos separa del final.

(Algunos artículos editados en esta revista han sido extraídos de la revista inglesa Dragon (Issue 232 - Aug 1996), Dragon (Issue 233 - Sep 1996), #234 y Dungeon (Issue 62 - Nov 1996)).

65624.description:
The Joy of Chit Chat
The Horror of RSP
The Tragic Normality of the regular forums

Experience BGG from the perspective of one of its most beloved Admins!

I will kick Matthew Monin in the ass if he doesn't update the description of this game

-Skelebone

A summary from the designer: An exciting little game about trying to be the best Octavian one can be. Which is not hard, despite all the house rules that he implemented mid play (which is within game play). A rigorous game of flagging and banning users/admins, trying to see who is the better octavian. And sad to say, it isn't MMM!
65624.name: The BGG Admin Game: The Octavian Edition

65625.name: Battles of 1866: Koniggratz
boardgamefamily: Wars of the States and Empires
65625.description:
One of the three games split off from the earlier War of the Empires: Battles of 1866 project from APL, this game covers the most famous battle from the Austro-Prussian War... Koniggratz. Rather than the five smaller battles in the Frontier Battles installment, this game focuses on one huge battle between the Prussians and Austrians.

This game uses the same system as War of the States: Gettysburg, 1863 and War Of The States: Chickamauga & Chattanooga which is similar to the Rome at War and Eagles Of The Empire series as well. In this game, the units are Prussian, Austrian, and Saxon infantry brigades artillery batteries, and cavalry regiments. The pieces are moved around topographic maps of the various battlegrounds. Combat is resolved using by rolling a number of dice equal to the total combat strength of units involved in combat, with hits scored on a result of 6.

65626.name: Battles of 1866: Custoza
boardgamefamily: Wars of the States and Empires
65626.description:
The last of the three games split off from the earlier Battles of 1866: Frontier Battles project from APL, this game covers the First and Second Battles of Custoza in northern Italy. The first battle pits Josef Graf Radetzky against Carlo Alberto's crack Piedmontese forces while the second takes place on the same battlefield nearly 20 years later.

This game uses the same system as War of the States: Gettysburg, 1863 and War of the States: Chickamauga & Chattanooga which is similar to the Rome at War and Eagles Of The Empire series as well. In this game, the units are Austrian, Italian, and Piedmontese infantry brigades, artillery batteries, and cavalry regiments. The pieces are moved around topographic maps of the various battlegrounds. Combat is resolved using by rolling a number of dice equal to the total combat strength of units involved in combat, with hits scored on a result of 6.

This game does not yet have its own webpage on the APL site.

65627.name: Modern Dispatch (Issue 113 - 2007)
65627.description:
From the scenario:

The long delayed Albenistan national elections have finally arrived. The campaigning has been short and, in many areas, violent. While Holy Motherland Albenistan was broken after its disasterous attempt to use a biological weapon in Khorfojan (the adventure from the Khorforjan Gambit), intelligence information indicates it is slowly rebuilding. Even without the HMA, the months leading up to the election have been marred by sectarian violence.

65628.name: Instant Bad Guys!
65628.description:
User summary:

2400 of pre-generated characters for the original version of Dungeons and Dragons and compatible games (including the Complete Warlock series).

Fighters, Magic Users, and Clerics of 1st through 10th level are included.

Written by the "Pasadena Playtest Group".

65629.name: Voice Sea Battle II
65629.description: Electronic game, both French and English voices, b Saitek. Includes not only regular ships, but different shaped spaceships for use. Similar to Electronic Battleship, but the space version used different shaped ships. Voice can be in either English or French. Standard battleships are the naval version, oddly shaped ships are the space based version.

boardgamehonor: 2010 Spiel der Spiele Hit für Kinder Recommended
65630.description: Players assemble a circle of tepees (tents), each made from two slotted playing cards. Dice are rolled, and players race to claim a tepee with the most matching symbols -- both inside and outside the tent! However, if an "X" (taboo!) is rolled the goal is reversed.
65630.name: Tipi
boardgamepodcastepisode: BGTG 110 - All About the Easy Play games (with David Arnott)

65631.name: Different Worlds (Issue 24 - Sep 1982)
65631.description:
Different Worlds
Issue 24
The Magazine of Game Role-Playing

Cover art by Brad W. Foster
Special Dwarf-Mostal Issue!

65632.name: Landlocked: Hither and Yon
65632.description:
Travel as you please, from hither to yon. Just don’t become Landlocked!

The goal is to construct a correct path through 12 locations. Moving orthogonally, move your pawn from the upper left to the null tile of your outbound suit. You may move your pawn through a higher-valued outbound tile en route to the current value your pawn is heading towards. However you may not pass through any tile on your inbound suit. Once this is done, you must mark each tile you passed through After all the tiles you passed through are marked, move on to the ace tile of your outbound suit, marking each tile you passed through as before. Continue on in this manner and in order to tiles Ace-5 of the outbound suit to 5-Null of the inbound suit. When you are working on your inbound suit, you may pass through any and all tiles on your outbound suit. However you may not pass through an inbound tile that has a value lower than the current value your pawn is moving towards.

65634.name: The Khorforjan Gambit
65634.description:
From the publisher:

Part Three of the Albenistan Series, a d20 Modern adventure supplement

Time is running out. Somewhere, a nationalist extremist has a deadly device he is preparing to unleash on an unsuspecting populace. The Albenistan military believes it knows where the device may be, but the Increment–the para-military, special operations wing of Great Britain’s Secret Intelligence Service–believes the extremist and his device has reached the city of Khorforjan, the center for the international effort to aid the refugees in the unstable region bordering Afghanistan. With no support and little time, the Increment team rushes to Khorforjan, hoping to avert the insane gambit of a remorseless criminal.
